original_conversation.content: Why do octopuses have three hearts?

Oh, well, that's actually, um, a really cool adaptation thing. Two of them pump blood to the gills while, you know, the third one handles circulation to the rest of the body. Pretty efficient system when you think about it.
Three hearts. That's [exhausted] excessive.

Ha! I mean, when you're living underwater and need to squeeze through tiny spaces, your body needs all the oxygen it can get. Plus they stop using that main heart when they swim, which is why they prefer crawling.
They stop their heart to swim?

Yeah! Wild, [gasp loudly] right? It's too exhausting for them to keep it pumping while swimming. Makes them vulnerable though, which is probably why you see them scooting along the ocean floor more often than swimming around.
What else stops its heart voluntarily?
Hmm, not many creatures do that on purpose. Some hibernating animals slow theirs way down, like wood frogs that basically freeze solid in winter. Their hearts completely stop until spring thaw.
Frozen frogs. So, uh, they're basically, like, dead then?

Kind of, yeah, but um, not really— it's more like, er, suspended animation. Their cells produce this natural antifreeze, glucose and urea, that prevents ice crystals from forming inside the cells and damaging them.

2.5 billion. Hmm, that's— wait, how do you even, like, calculate that?

Oh it's, uh, pretty straightforward math actually— about 70 beats per minute, er, times 60 minutes, times 24 hours, times 365 days, times, well, roughly 70 years. Give or take depending on fitness level and stress.
